These are good bills that take concrete action to make it harder to commit acts of violence with a gun. Our most basic responsibility as elected officials is to protect our communities & children, so I’m asking my colleagues to step up & do your duty to keep our kids safe.

The No Crime Left Behind Act would bar those who have been convicted of a misdemeanor involving a firearm from buying a gun for three years, so we can keep guns out of the hands of individuals who have proven they can’t handle them responsibly.

The Gun Violence Prevention Research Act would authorize $50 million per fiscal year over the next five years to boost the CDC’s firearms safety and gun violence prevention research, so that we can start studying gun violence and get the data we need to fight this epidemic.

The Safe Guns; Safe Kids Act – written based on the circumstances of the shooting at Oxford High School – would require parents to secure their firearms when a child is in the home and hold them responsible if the child uses the firearm to commit a crime.

The Pause for Gun Safety Act – written based on the circumstances of the shooting at MSU – would require a one-week waiting or “cooling off” period before a person may receive a firearm, so that they can’t use it in a fit of rage or crisis.

If Republicans want to come to the table in good faith, on serious bipartisan efforts to streamline the permitting process and lower energy costs for American families, I will be the first one in line.

What House Republicans are doing is this: they are holding an antiquated permitting system hostage to extract benefits for big oil corporations. It was well within their power to separate these two elements of H.R. 1.
For me, it all comes down to ensuring a future for the next generation of West Michiganders. This legislation goes directly against ensuring a green future for our kids and their kids.
H.R. 1 goes against these goals. MI-03 is home to a large portion of the Grand River watershed and miles of Lake Michigan shoreline. I’m very serious about protecting these natural resources.

I talk to West Michiganders every day about what they want and need. The majority of us want to protect the Great Lakes—and that means investing in conservation efforts and putting smart regulations in place that support the longevity of the Great Lakes economy.

This bill includes massive handouts to huge corporations, many of whom profited off of high gas prices. H.R. 1 makes it easier to drill on federal lands through a provision called LECA (leak-a)–you just can’t make this stuff up.
There’s an easier way to do this than H.R. 1: separate the question. Why aren't Republicans doing this? The answer is pretty clear, and it's in the text of the bill itself.
There's no question we desperately need permitting reform in this country to get the U.S. to energy independence and transition to green energy. A 🧵…
